questions.question_text:
A company uses a model-driven app to record customers’ dietary preferences.

You need to change the order of the columns in a personal view that you created on the Contact table.

Where should you change the order?

discussion.content:
B. App designer
Views can be developed through the table designer or the app designer.
reference: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/model-driven-apps/create-edit-views
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/power-apps/maker/model-driven-apps/create-edit-views-app-designer

The correct answer is C. Model-driven app.
In a model-driven app, you can change the order of columns in a personal view by going to the Contact table, clicking on the "Views" tab, and then clicking on the three dots next to the personal view you want to modify. From there, you can select "Edit" and then drag and drop the columns in the desired order.

Power Apps Studio (A) is a visual development environment where you build apps from scratch, whereas this scenario is related to modifying an existing table in a model-driven app.

App designer (B) is not a valid option in this context.

Microsoft Power Platform admin center (D) is a centralized platform for managing Power Platform resources, but it's not where you would typically make changes to a specific table or view in a model-driven app.

Selected Answer: C
Copilot says C:
To change the order of the columns in a personal view that you created on the Contact table, you should use the Model-driven app (C).

Within the Model-driven app, you can customize personal views by rearranging the columns to suit your preferences. This allows you to tailor the view based on how you want the data to be displayed.

 canvas apps allow the app creator to have full control over the user interface, design, and color scheme of the app. Canvas apps can also connect to multiple data sources, such as SharePoint, Microsoft 365, Dynamics 365, SQL Server, and more. Canvas apps also have the ability to scan barcodes using the BarcodeScanner control.
Model-driven apps, on the other hand, are based on the data model and business logic defined in the Microsoft Dataverse database. Model-driven apps use business process flows to guide users through a data entry process, such as creating a new record, updating an existing record, or completing a task. Model-driven apps have a consistent look and feel across screens, but offer less customization options than canvas apps
